awd_titl_txt: Arkansas Delta Information Systems and Cyber Technician Education Initiative
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a growing demand for qualified technicians in information systems technology and cyber security.  In rural areas such as the Arkansas Delta region, this demand is even stronger because of a severe talent shortage in the information security workforce. Unfortunately, students pursuing education in these fields may be underprepared for even introductory courses.  As a result, they need additional tutoring and other academic supports to be successful. Financial constraints also make it difficult for students to obtain the necessary resources to complete their degree or other training programs. This project aims to increase the capacity to prepare information systems and cyber technicians to enter the workforce. Specifically, Phillips Community College of the University of Arkansas will implement strategies to increase the quality and capacity of skilled technicians completing degrees or certificates in the College's Information Systems program. The project also aims to increase the quality and capacity of faculty who have the required credentials to teach in the program. Graduates of the program are expected to help meet the demand in the job market across the tristate area of Arkansas, Mississippi, and Tennessee. 

This project will implement activities designed to support students and faculty. Student recruitment activities include summer workshops, high school outreach, and lunchtime career information sessions. Student retention and support activities include tutoring and study groups. Experiential education, including the use of hands-on experiences and high-tech virtualization products, will expand and enhance the curriculum by giving students the opportunity to connect classroom knowledge with real world experiences.  Additional hybrid and online courses will serve students who are unable to participate in traditional face-to-face classes. Partnerships with industry will be expanded and an industrial advisory board will help guide the program and connect students with internship and job opportunities. Finally, faculty training and certification support will ensure that faculty use the most effective pedagogy and students acquire the most current content. This project will strengthen the connections between the college and the community by providing the opportunity for graduates to secure technician jobs in the area, fill the employment gap, and become vital members of the community. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: Arkansas Delta Information Systems and Cyber (DISC) Initiative
Director/PI: Monica Quattlebaum ? Cynthia Grove
Federal Award ID: 1901877

In July 2019, Phillips Community College of the University of Arkansas (PCCUA) received an NSF ATE project award entitled Arkansas Delta Information Systems and Cyber Education Initiative. This project, including goals, objectives, and activities, is to increase the quality and capacity of the graduates in the information systems and cyber technicians? fields, create a stronger relationship with industry partners, increase qualified faculty, and fill the demand for networking, programming, and cyber security skills needed for industry. This project developed and implemented recruitment and retention strategies for students, provided support to maximize student success, developed and revised curriculum to meet the changes in the information technology field, provided professional development for faculty to ensure high-quality teaching and learning, and continued to strengthen the bond between industry and business leaders in the community.

Enhancing and Broadening Intellectual Merit: this initiative proved to have a high impact in the Arkansas Delta region by providing the necessary resources for faculty to educate and train information systems technicians. The project allowed for the development and implementation of recruitment and retention strategies for students which also provided support through computer labs, instructor led tutoring sessions, and high-tech simulation software to maximize student success. Faculty developed and revised curriculum to align with the industry standards and meet the demand of business and industry.  Faculty implemented virtualized learning environments to connect the classroom with real world applications while also gaining experience with essential hardware and software needed to be successful in the information technology environment. Faculty received professional development to ensure high-quality instruction for students to be prepared to enter the workforce while also strengthen the bond between industry and business leaders in the community. This project provided the community with the caliber of technicians who are ready and able to face the challenges of the continuously changing Information Technology and Cyber Security fields. The Team-Teaching Model combined with the enhanced curriculum provided alternative delivery methods such as in-person, hybrid, and online learning to maximize accessibility to all students and increase enrollment by 20% per year. Student retention increased by 5% per year, 80% of graduates were prepared for industry certification exams, and 70% of graduates either transferred to continue their education or entered the information technology workforce.

Broadening Impacts: this initiative expanded and enhanced its information systems and cyber security programs, served as a model to other institutions who seek to enhance their information systems and cyber security programs, strengthened the connections between the College and community, and impacted local industries and businesses by providing highly skilled technicians that meet critical job demands. Through professional development, training, and conferences, faculty implemented new teaching strategies that led to student success and provided the students with the skills needed to be productive information systems and cyber security technicians in the industry. Faculty hosted online bootcamps to help students review and prepare for industry certification exams.  Faculty also conducted campus-wide trainings on cyber security awareness and shared best practices to protect against cyber-attacks. Through the project, faculty implemented additional hands-on and virtual labs to allow students to connect classroom knowledge with real-world experiences to prepare them for high-tech, high-demand jobs in the information technology industry.

Expanding Student Participation: this initiative provided opportunities for expanding student participation in the program and college activities. During the project's tenure, the College established a student cyber security organization that opened additional educational and employment opportunities for the student body and increased the number of students in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics). 

Because of the initiative, infrastructure increased to support faculty efforts to improve student learning and success in the program; the Team-Teaching Model provided students with more one-on-one instructions; students obtained more certificates of proficiency; graduate numbers increased; graduates exited the program with more industry certifications; retention rates increased; a new faculty member was added; the College programs gained more industry awareness; and a higher percentage of students entered the workforce upon completion of the program.

Summary: Arkansas Delta Information Systems and Cyber Education Initiative contributed to creating a more expansive information systems and cyber security program at Phillips Community College of the University of Arkansas (PCCUA). Through this project the College recognized an increase in the number of qualified faculty to teach in the program which also impacted the number of qualified technicians that graduate and enter the information systems and cyber security workforce industry.

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2023
Modified by: Cindy Grove
